Gravity from entropy


Gravity from entropy

Ginestra Bianconi *

School of Mathematical Sciences, Queen Mary University of London, London, E1 4NS, United Kingdom

(Received 26 August 2024; accepted 27 January 2025; published 3 March 2025)

Gravity is derived from an entropic action coupling matter fields with geometry. The fundamental idea is
to relate the metric of Lorentzian spacetime to a quantum operator, playing the role of an renormalizable
effective density matrix and to describe the matter fields topologically, according to a Dirac-Kähler
formalism, as the direct sum of a 0-form, a 1-form and a 2-form. While the geometry of spacetime is
defined by its metric, the matter fields can be used to define an alternative metric, the metric induced by the
matter fields, which geometrically describes the interplay between spacetime and matter. The proposed
entropic action is the quantum relative entropy between the metric of spacetime and the metric induced by
the matter fields. The modified Einstein equations obtained from this action reduce to the Einstein
equations with zero cosmological constant in the regime of low coupling. By introducing theG-field, which
acts as a set of Lagrangian multipliers, the proposed entropic action reduces to a dressed Einstein-Hilbert
action with an emergent small and positive cosmological constant only dependent on the G-field. The
obtained equations of modified gravity remain second order in the metric and in the G-field. A canonical
quantization of this field theory could bring new insights into quantum gravity while further research might
clarify the role that the G-field could have for dark matter.

DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevD.111.066001

I. INTRODUCTION

The relation between general relativity, statistical
mechanics and information theory is a central research
topic in theoretical physics. The interest in the subject has
its roots in the discovery that black holes have an
entropy [1,2] and emit Hawking radiation [3]. Recently,
important results have been obtained relating information
theory, entanglement entropy [4–6] and gravity [7–13]
involving the holographic principle [14–16], the entangle-
ment properties of quantum field theory and the theory of
von Neumann algebras [17,18].
These results define a very active research direction [19]

indicating that the quest for an ultimate gravitational
theory based on information theory and statistical mechan-
ics is ongoing. A comprehensive statistical mechanics
approach to gravity is expected to give rise to modified
Einstein equations [20–22] that on the one side can be
testable experimentally [23,24] while on the other side
can bring important conceptual insights into the ultimate
theory for black holes [25], dark matter [26] and quantum
gravity [27–32].

In this work, a continuum modified theory of gravity
based on a statistical mechanics action is considered. This
theory treats the metric at each point of spacetime as a
“renomalizable” density matrix, or more precisely a local
quantum operator. This central idea is relating geometry
with the mathematical foundation of quantum field
theory [33] and is inspired by the used of von Neumann
algebras in explaining entanglement in field theories [17,18]
and quantum gravity [34–36]. While the geometry of
spacetime is defined through its associated metric, the
interplay between matter fields and geometry is captured by
the metric induced by the matter fields which describes how
the matter fields effectively curve spacetime. Embracing a
statistical mechanics approach to gravity, this work inter-
prets these metric tensors as quantum operators and
postulates an action for gravity given by the quantum
relative entropy between the metric of the manifold and the
metric induced by the matter fields. From the mathematical
point of view, the quantum relative entropy proposed in this
work is strictly related to the Araki quantum relative
entropy for von Neumann algebras [17,37–39]. From the
physics point of view, the proposed action fully describes
how matter curves geometry and how geometry affects the
matter fields.
A crucial aspect of the proposed theory is the adoption of

a topological (Dirac-Kähler like [40,41]) description
of bosonic matter fields. Note that the extension of
Dirac-Kähler and staggered fermions formalism to bosonic
particles is gaining increasing interest in lattice gauge

induced by the topological matter fields is expressed in
terms of the Hodge-Dirac operator [45]. From this stat-

modified Einstein equations by introducing an auxiliary
field associated to gravity which we call G-field. The
introduction of this new field is justified as it acts as a set of
Lagragian multipliers enforcing linear constraints on metric
induced by the matter fields. In this way the G-field extends
the popular use of the Legendre transformation in fðRÞ
theories [20,22]. Given the particular entropic structure of
the action, the modified Einstein equations take a very
simplified expression. The gravitational part of the action
takes the form of a dressed Einstein-Hilbert action in which
we observe an emergent positive cosmological constant
that depends exclusively on the G-field.
This work greatly expands on previous results [44]

obtained in the discrete setting by the same author. On
one side, here a continuum and fully Lorentz invariant
theory is proposed. This progress is based on the develop-
ment of the suitable mathematical framework to define the
Lorentz invariant entropy and cross-entropy between
the metric of the spacetime and the metric induced by
the matter fields. On the other side, here the relation of this
statistical mechanics/information theory action with the
Einstein-Hilbert action [46,47] is established defining a
clear connection to gravity. Two fundamental aspects of
this work that are not present in Ref. [44] are relevant to
clearly relate this approach to gravity. First, this work
considers a local theory, defining the entropy of the metric
at each point of spacetime, while the previous work
considers only the entropy associated to the full metric
of the higher-order network. The present local theory
allows a closer connection to gravity and constitutes a
step forward to establish the connection between this
approach and the quantum theory of entanglement [17].
Secondly, by adopting the continuum limit, in this work the
intrinsic difficulty related to the definition of the curvature
of networks, simplicial and cell complexes is avoided.
To keep the discussion concise the focus is here mostly

on scalar (bosonic) matter fields, and their topological
generalizations with a brief mention in Appendix A of the
natural extension of this framework to Abelian gauge
fields, while in Ref. [44] the theory covers also fer-
mionic matter fields. Further extensions of the proposed
local framework to Dirac and non-Abelian gauge fields
[44,48,49] in the continuum or in the discrete setting are left
for future investigations.
This work is structured as follows. In Sec. II we provide

the motivation of the proposed theory and we discuss
preliminary results on an instructive warm-up scenario. In
Sec. III we outline the proposed theoretical framework, we

postulate the entropic action for gravity and we derive the
corresponding modified Einstein equations. In Sec. IV we
provide the concluding remarks. The paper also includes
three Appendixes discussing possible extensions of the
proposed theoretical framework, providing the mathemati-
cal background and all the necessary details regarding the
notation used in Sec. III, and establishing the connection of
the present theory with the theory of local quantum
operators and the Araki entropy.

In this section our goal is to investigate the property of

this end we introduce the auxiliary G-field G̃ and the

Several modified gravity actions are questioned because

IV. CONCLUSIONS

This work proposes a modified theory of gravity
emerging from statistical mechanics and information theory
action. The fundamental idea of this theory is to associate
the metric to a quantum operator, playing the role of a
renormalizable and effective density matrix. In particular
two metrics are discussed: the metric of spacetime that fully
defines its geometry and the metric induced by matter fields
that are effectively curving the space. The interplay
between geometry of spacetime and matter fields is
explicitly captured by the proposed action given by the
quantum relative entropy between the metric and the metric
induced by the matter fields.
Here a Lorentzian theory consistent with this fundamen-

tal physical interpretation of gravity is formulated. In order
to do this we have built the necessary mathematical
background to define the entropy and the cross-entropy
of metric tensors in a Lorentzian well defined way. A
modified gravity is emerging from this framework when the
matter fields are described by topological Dirac-Kähler
bosons formed by the direct sum between a 0-form, a
1-form and a 2-form and the induced metric also depends
on the curvature of spacetime. The modified Einstein
equations reduce to the Einstein equations in the regime
of low coupling. By introducing the G-field we obtain the
modified Einstein equations and the equations of motion
for the matter and the G-field. From this theory it emerges
that the proposed entropic action takes the form of a sum
between a dressed Einstein-Hilbert action and a matter
action. Interestingly, the dressed Einstein-Hilbert action
displays an emergent positive cosmological constant that
only depends on the G-field. Moreover, thanks to the
introduction of the G-field, the equations of modified
gravity remain second order in the metric, in the matter
and in the G-field.
The interpretation of the topological metrics tensors as

quantum operators, or effective density matrix where we
have relaxed the constraints of having unitary trace, and we
have required the existence of the inverse, is shown to be
very useful. These choices are motivated here by the
necessity to have a Lorentzian invariant theory. Here we
have established the relation of the adopted quantum
relative action with Araki quantum relative entropy [37],
opening the perspective of using the theory of quantum von
Neumann algebras and the theory of entanglement [17] to
investigate further the properties of the proposed theory.

Below is a structured explanation of the main ideas, methods, and results of the paper “Gravity from Entropy” (Phys. Rev. D 111, 066001 (2025)) by Ginestra Bianconi. The paper proposes a novel way to derive gravity from a statistical-mechanics- or information-theory-based action, where the metric of spacetime is treated as a “quantum operator.”

---

## 1. Motivation and Context

1. **Thermodynamics & Gravity**  
   The relationship between gravity and thermodynamics (in particular, the discovery of black-hole entropy and Hawking radiation) suggests that spacetime itself might be understood in terms of entropy or information. Jacobson’s derivation of Einstein’s equations from thermodynamic arguments, and various entanglement-entropy approaches to gravity, are prominent examples of these ideas.

2. **Quantum Relative Entropy and Operators**  
   In quantum information theory, the relative entropy between two density matrices (or more general “quantum operators”) is a key measure of how different two quantum states are. The author’s central idea is to interpret the spacetime metric as one such operator. Because the usual metric does not have trace 1 (and can be singular under certain conditions), the paper regards the metric only as a *positive-definite operator*—akin to a density matrix, but without the unit-trace constraint.

3. **Dirac–Kähler (Topological) Matter Fields**  
   While one might guess that “matter fields” means just scalar or vector fields, the author uses a “topological Dirac–Kähler” formalism, in which one packages bosonic matter into a sum of forms (0-form, 1-form, and 2-form). This can also be extended to include gauge fields (Appendix A) and, in other contexts, fermionic fields as well. One key advantage is that this approach naturally includes mass-like terms and curvature couplings while fitting well with the entropy-based picture.

---

## 2. Core Construction of the Entropic Action

### 2.1 Two Metrics: g̃ (the spacetime metric) and G̃ (the induced metric)

- **Default Metric \( g̃ \)**  
  One views the “default” spacetime geometry as encoded by a rank-2 Lorentzian metric \(g_{\mu\nu}\). This naturally induces higher-form metrics too: for instance, the 2-form metric \(g^{(2)}\) and so forth. Collectively, the *topological metric* \(g̃\) is the direct sum of:
  \[
    g̃ \;=\; 1 
             \;\oplus\; g_{\mu\nu}\,dx^\mu \otimes dx^\nu
             \;\oplus\; g^{(2)}_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}\,\bigl(dx^\mu \wedge dx^\nu\bigr)\otimes\bigl(dx^\rho \wedge dx^\sigma\bigr).
  \]
  Here,
  \[
    g^{(2)}_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma} 
    \;=\;\tfrac12\,\bigl(g_{\mu\rho}\,g_{\nu\sigma} - g_{\mu\sigma}\,g_{\nu\rho}\bigr)
  \]
  provides a natural metric on 2-forms.

- **Induced Metric \( G̃ \)**  
  The paper then posits that, given a set of matter fields (0-forms, 1-forms, and 2-forms all together), one obtains another topological metric \(G̃\). For example, if \(\Phi\) denotes the full Dirac–Kähler field, then one builds \(G̃\) using:
  1. Terms that couple directly to derivatives of \(\Phi\) (analogous to “DjΦ⟩⟨ΦjD”).
  2. Mass terms (with a factor \((m^2 + \xi\,R)\) multiplying \(\Phi\) in some projector-like way).
  3. A piece that depends explicitly on the spacetime curvature (\(R_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}\), etc.) and “mixes” geometry with matter.

  Concretely, for scalar fields \(\phi\), or 1-forms \(\omega_\mu\), one can imagine a simpler expression like  
  \[
    G_{\mu\nu} \;=\; g_{\mu\nu} \;+\; \alpha\,[(\nabla \phi)(\nabla \phi)^\dagger]_{\mu\nu} \;-\;\beta\,[\text{Curvature terms}],
  \]
  with higher-form analogs. The constants \(\alpha, \beta\) set coupling strengths.

### 2.2 The Quantum Relative Entropy as the Action

1. **Entropy of a Metric**  
   Interpreted as an operator, a positive-definite metric \(G_{\mu\nu}\) can be diagonalized to find its eigenvalues \(\{\lambda_i\}\). One then defines the (von Neumann–like) entropy of \(G\) as
   \[
     H(G) \;=\; \mathrm{Tr}\bigl[G\,\ln(G^{-1})\bigr]
              \;=\; -\!\sum_i\,\lambda_i \,\ln(\lambda_i).
   \]
   However, the *default* metric \(g\) (or \(g^{(n)}\) for each form-degree) has all eigenvalues identically 1, so its entropy is *zero*.

2. **Relative Entropy**  
   The action uses the *quantum relative entropy* between \(g̃\) and \(G̃\). Because \(\mathrm{Entropy}(g̃)=0\), the relative-entropy expression simplifies to
   \[
     \mathcal{L}
     \;=\;
     \mathrm{Tr}_{g̃}\!\bigl[\ln\bigl(G̃^{-1}\bigr)\bigr] 
     \;=\; 
     -\,\mathrm{Tr}_{F}\!\Bigl[\ln\bigl(G̃\,g̃^{-1}\bigr)\Bigr],
   \]
   where the subscript “\(\mathrm{Tr}_{F}\)” or “\(\mathrm{Tr}_{g̃}\)” indicates taking the appropriate Lorentz-invariant trace over all form-degrees. The full action is then
   \[
     S
     \;=\;
     \frac{1}{l_{\mathrm{P}}^{\,d}}
     \int \sqrt{-\,g}\;\mathcal{L}\;d^dr.
   \]
   This is the key ansatz: **gravity emerges as the variational principle of a relative-entropy measure** between two large “operator-like” objects (the “bare” topological metric vs. an “induced” topological metric).

### 2.3 Introduction of a G-field

- Because the action above is *nonlinear* in \(G̃\), one can rewrite it via a Lagrange-multiplier trick and introduce an auxiliary field \(G̃\) (called the G-field in the paper) plus another auxiliary \(\Thetã\). These fields act somewhat like “Legendre transforms” do in \(f(R)\)-type modified gravities. After introducing them, the theory can be expressed so that curvature terms appear only at second derivative order—a key sign that one avoids the Ostrogradsky instability.

- Interpreting these new fields as genuine degrees of freedom (not just formal Lagrange multipliers) changes the structure of the solutions. One ends up with a *dressed Einstein–Hilbert action* containing an *emergent positive cosmological constant* \(\Lambda_G\) that depends on the G-field.

---

## 3. Equations of Motion and Main Results

### 3.1 Matter-Field Equations

From varying the action with respect to the matter fields (the Dirac–Kähler forms), one gets field equations resembling generalized, curved-space Klein–Gordon or Maxwell-like equations. In the low-coupling limit (small \(\alpha\), \(\beta\)), these reduce to standard wave equations with mass and curvature couplings.

### 3.2 Modified Einstein Equations

Varying the same entropic action with respect to the metric \(g_{\mu\nu}\) yields *modified* Einstein equations:
\[
  R^{G}_{(\mu\nu)} 
  \;-\;\tfrac12\,g_{\mu\nu}\,\bigl(R^{G} \,-\,2\,\Lambda_G\bigr)
  \;+\; D_{(\mu\nu)}
  \;=\;
  \kappa\,T_{(\mu\nu)},
\]
where

- \(R^{G}_{\mu\nu}\) is a “dressed” Ricci tensor that depends on the G-field,  
- \(\Lambda_G\) is an emergent, *positive* cosmological constant, also entirely determined by the G-field,  
- \(T_{(\mu\nu)}\) is the usual-looking stress-energy tensor for the matter fields, and  
- \(D_{(\mu\nu)}\) contains second derivatives of the G-field (no derivatives higher than two appear).

In the regime where \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are small (or equivalently, the induced metric \(G̃\) is “close” to the bare metric \(g̃\)), one recovers ordinary Einstein equations, plus standard matter terms, and **zero** cosmological constant in that limit. For slightly larger coupling, there is a small, positive \(\Lambda_G\), with interesting implications for cosmology.

### 3.3 Role of the G-field and Cosmological Constant

- The paper highlights that the G-field behaves like a set of Lagrange multipliers enforcing how the induced metric is a function of both the matter fields and curvature. In the fully dynamical interpretation, \(\Lambda_G\) emerges as a function of G-field degrees of freedom and can be small yet nonzero, which might connect to dark-energy-like effects.

- The equations remain second-order in the metric and in the G-field, meaning one might avoid pathologies of higher-derivative modifications of general relativity.

---

## 4. Interpretations and Outlook

1. **Quantum-Operator View of the Metric**  
   A major conceptual point is: one treats the metric as though it were an “effective density matrix.” Usually density matrices have unit trace, but here that constraint is lifted. In mathematics of von Neumann algebras, it is known that “non-trace-1 positive operators” can still yield well-defined generalizations of relative entropy—this is akin to the Araki relative entropy.

2. **Possible Connection to Quantum Gravity**  
   Because the construction uses quantum relative entropy, there is a suggestion that this approach might shed light on the unification of quantum mechanics and gravity. In particular, the formalism is reminiscent of local quantum operator algebras in quantum field theory. The hope is that looking at the metric as a quantum operator in a larger Hilbert space might simplify attempts at second-quantized or entanglement-based descriptions of gravity.

3. **Small Emergent Cosmological Constant**  
   A phenomenon of interest is that the theory naturally produces an emergent, *positive* cosmological constant. If the G-field can relax in certain ways, one might get a small but nonzero \(\Lambda_G\) that could be relevant to cosmic acceleration. How robust or finely tuned that is would require further analysis.

4. **Dark Matter and Other Extensions**  
   The paper briefly alludes to the possibility that the G-field might play a role akin to dark matter. Because the G-field introduces extra degrees of freedom beyond the standard metric, it could mimic additional gravitational effects. One could explore whether it yields extra “halolike” mass distribution on galactic scales or otherwise modifies local gravitational dynamics.

5. **Future Work**  
   - Detailed phenomenological tests (post-Newtonian expansions, gravitational-wave constraints, etc.).  
   - Stability analyses (e.g. Hamiltonian analysis, avoiding ghosts).  
   - Coupling to other (fermionic) matter or non-Abelian gauge fields.  
   - Exploring quantum corrections and renormalization flows.  

---

## 5. Summary

**Key Achievement**  
The paper provides a new, consistent framework in which *gravity can be viewed as emerging from an entropic action*—namely, the quantum relative entropy between the usual metric and a matter-induced metric. In the “low-coupling” limit, one recovers the standard Einstein–Hilbert action (with zero cosmological constant) plus normal matter fields. When one includes additional curvature and topological terms in the induced metric, a *modified* theory of gravity arises, featuring an auxiliary G-field and a small, positive cosmological constant that depends on this auxiliary field.

**Conceptual Significance**  
This approach unifies ideas from quantum information (relative entropy), from geometry (metrics on higher forms), and from quantum field theory (where operators can be associated to geometry). It points to an intriguing view of Einstein’s equations and might offer a new road to bridging quantum mechanics and gravity.

---

### References and Further Reading

- The paper itself: G. Bianconi, “Gravity from Entropy,” *Phys. Rev. D* 111, 066001 (2025).  
- Connections to relative entropy and Araki’s theorem in quantum operator algebras: Araki, *Publ. RIMS* (Kyoto) **11**, 809 (1975).  
- Jacobson’s thermodynamic derivation of Einstein’s equations: *Phys. Rev. Lett.* **75**, 1260 (1995).  
- Dirac–Kähler fermions: P. Becher and H. Joos, *Z. Phys. C* **15**, 343 (1982).  
- f(R) theories and modified gravity: Sotiriou and Faraoni, *Rev. Mod. Phys.* **82**, 451 (2010).

This completes the core explanation. The core idea is straightforward to state—*treat the metric as a quantum operator and use quantum relative entropy as the action*—but its ramifications for both classical and (potentially) quantum gravity are extensive.
